headline.main: California Health Insurer Will Issue Refunds

docs.abstract: The state's Blue Shield said it had pledged to cap profits at 2 percent.
docs.snippet: The state's Blue Shield said it had pledged to cap profits at 2 percent.

docs.lead_paragraph: Blue Shield of California, a large nonprofit health insurer based in San Francisco, said on Thursday that it planned to return an additional $295 million to its customers as part of the pledge it made earlier this year to cap its earnings to 2 percent of its revenue.

docs.lead_paragraph: Saving money while saving the planet calls for scrimping and creativity.
docs.abstract: Many eco-conscious consumers are cutting their spending on green products, finding it difficult to justify buying more expensive household items and organic foods in today's bad economy. Tips on making homemade cleaners and chart comparing prices of environmentally friendly and standard household products noted.
docs.snippet: Saving money while saving the planet calls for scrimping and creativity.

docs.lead_paragraph: 5:51 p.m. | Updated Republicans are months away from their first presidential primaries and caucuses, but the Obama campaign already is giving Mitt Romney the nominee treatment -- trying to define him irrevocably as a shape-shifter, with an eye to the 2012 election. On the morning after Tuesday's debate in New Hampshire among eight Republican rivals, the Obama campaign's senior strategist, David Axelrod, held a conference call for reporters and singled out Mr. Romney. According to Mr. Axelrod, the latest evidence of the former Massachusetts governor's inconsistency was his repeated claims of being an advocate for the middle class, even as he opposed President Obama's proposed extension of a payroll tax cut for about 160 million households.

docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time, a government-backed quality rating will have a financial meaning to health insurance companies looking to attract millions of older Americans to privately run Medicare coverage next year.
